justification: “These models typically make use of the drift-diffusion model (DDM; Ratcliff & McKoon, 2008), a widely-used cognitive model in decision-making, as their generative model of choice and reaction time data.”
construct: latent cognitive processes underlying decision making

justification: The paper notes that “zC comprises of three parameters including drift rate δ …” and later reports “Spearman correlations between fitted drift rates (δ) and choice-RTs are negatively strong,” indicating drift rate is the quantitative index for evidence-accumulation speed.

The cognitive latent vector “zC comprises of three parameters including … boundary α,” and the model analyses show “strong positive correlations between boundaries (α) and choice-RTs,” confirming α is the measure of decision caution.

Within zC “non-decision time (ndt) τ” is listed as one of the three latent cognitive parameters, and the results discuss correlations between estimated non-decision time and reaction times, demonstrating τ operationalises non-decision processes.

The authors state that the original study “found strong relationships between N200 latency and choice-RT, and thus the N200 is a good validation of our model,” implying N200 latency serves as a neural measure of when the decision process begins.
